channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Russian counteroffensive in Ukrainian-controlled Kursk begins, says Zelensky
item.dc:creator: Anastacia Galouchka, Lizzie Johnson
item.description: Zelensky said that the Russian counteroffensive had long been expected and was planned for.

item.title: Kyiv’s bombed children’s hospital rebuilds, and one boy heads home
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Johnson, Anastacia Galouchka
item.description: Hundreds with severe medical needs were displaced by July’s missile strike on Okhmatdyt Children’s Hospital in Kyiv, but the hospital was rebuilt and many returned.

item.title: A new crisis may plunge Libya back into chaos
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The recent dramas gripping the country have been shadowy, shaped by backroom deals, black market transfers and illicit smuggling.

item.title: Is the new statue of the late Queen Elizabeth II really that ... bad?
item.dc:creator: María Luisa Paúl
item.description: The newly unveiled sculpture at Antrim Castle Gardens in Northern Ireland was compared online to Robin Williams’s character in the 1993 movie “Mrs. Doubtfire.”

item.title: Afghan women defy Taliban and continue medical school in Scotland
item.dc:creator: Daniel Wu
item.description: The Scottish government granted free tuition to female students from Afghanistan to continue studying medicine after the Taliban upended their education.

item.title: U.N. agency says six of its staff among those killed in Israeli strikes
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel, Hazem Balousha, Frances Vinall, Victoria Bisset, Adam Taylor
item.description: The workers were killed when two airstrikes hit a Gaza refugee camp, said UNRWA, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees. Israel said it targeted Hamas militants.

item.title: Gaza’s traumatized children are facing another lost year of school
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Hajar Harb
item.description: About 650,000 students are missing their second school year, an absence educators say will compound the trauma of war and could cause lasting developmental problems.

item.title: More than half of Brazil is racked by drought. Blame deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy
item.description: Latin America’s largest country is being baked by its worst drought on record.

item.title: Iran turns to Hells Angels and other criminal gangs to target critics
item.dc:creator: Greg Miller, Souad Mekhennet, Cate Brown
item.description: Iran has cultivated ties with criminal networks in the West to carry out a recent wave of violent plots in the United States and Europe.

item.title: Which countries have suspended or restricted arms sales to Israel?
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih, Leo Sands
item.description: Canada is the latest country to suspend some weapons exports, amid scrutiny over military aid to Israel as the war in Gaza nears the one-year mark.

item.title: Amid Gaza talks, U.S. releases $1.3 billion in military aid to Egypt
item.dc:creator: Missy Ryan, Abigail Hauslohner
item.description: The Biden administration had previously withheld some annual funding from Egypt amid scrutiny of its human rights record.

item.title: New video, witnesses challenge Israel’s account of U.S. activist’s killing
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Loveday Morris, Meg Kelly, Jarrett Ley, Sufian Taha
item.description: The IDF said Aysenur Eygi was shot “unintentionally” during a “violent riot.” A Post analysis shows clashes had subsided and protesters had retreated.

item.title: Biden ‘outraged’ by U.S. activist’s death; Israel kills dozens in Gaza strikes
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel, Leo Sands, Heba Farouk Mahfouz
item.description: Israel carried out at least four airstrikes in Gaza and mounted raids in two West Bank villages.

item.title: As U.S. and Ukraine debate arms restrictions, Blinken visits Kyiv
item.dc:creator: Michael Birnbaum, Siobhán O'Grady, Ellen Francis
item.description: Kyiv’s attempt to sway the Biden administration comes as Ukraine has faced heavy bombardment from Russia in recent days — especially on its power sector.

item.title: Trump debate claims about German energy policy are wrong, says Berlin
item.dc:creator: Kate Brady
item.description: “We are shutting down — not building — coal and nuclear plants,” Germany’s Foreign Ministry said on social media in response to Trump’s debate comments.

item.title: House GOP maneuvers to portray Democrats as weak on China
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner, Cate Cadell, Marianna Sotomayor
item.description: With its “China Week” blitz of legislation, the House GOP seeks to bolster the party’s foreign policy credentials ahead of November’s election.

item.title: Global outlets pick apart debate, with many saying Harris came out on top
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman
item.description: Reactions to the Trump-Harris debate showed how closely countries are watching for signs of how November’s presidential election could affect their U.S. ties.

item.title: Meet Margarita Simonyan, queen of Russia’s covert information wars
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon
item.description: While the Kremlin has denied U.S. accusations of information operations, Simonyan proudly admits that her work is at the behest of the Russian government.
